prior_works.title: Trellis-Coded Quantization of Memoryless Sources
prior_works.authors: Michael W. Marcellin, Thomas R. Fischer
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduces TCQ with Viterbi decoding and set-partitioned labeling, the core idea QTIP adapts to enable ultra–high-dimensional quantization with a stateful decoder that decouples effective dimension from codebook size.

prior_works.title: Vector Quantization and Signal Compression
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the theoretical underpinnings for high-dimensional quantization and shaping gains, and formalizes the exponential codebook-scaling barrier in VQ that QTIP overcomes via TCQ.

prior_works.title: Channel Coding with Multilevel/Phase Signals (Trellis-Coded Modulation)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Ungerboeck’s set-partitioning and trellis construction principles directly inform the code design and labeling strategies QTIP uses to build hardware-efficient ‘bitshift’ trellises.

prior_works.title: Error Bounds for Convolutional Codes and an Asymptotically Optimum Decoding Algorithm
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The Viterbi algorithm is the dynamic-programming backbone for TCQ; QTIP relies on this stateful decoding to quantize sequences of weights efficiently across very high effective dimensions.

prior_works.title: Product Quantization for Nearest Neighbor Search
prior_works.authors: Hervé Jégou, Matthijs Douze, Cordelia Schmid
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrates how practical VQ resorts to low-dimensional subspaces to avoid exponential codebooks—exactly the limitation QTIP removes by using TCQ to achieve high-dimensional shaping without massive codebooks.

prior_works.title: Additive Quantization for Extreme Vector Compression
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Shows that combining simple codebooks can approximate rich, high-dimensional structure; QTIP’s spectrum from lookup-only to computed lookup-free trellis codes echoes this compositional efficiency in a trellis framework.

prior_works.title: Additive Power-of-Two Quantization: An Efficient Non-uniform Quantization for Deep Neural Networks
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduces shift/add-friendly quantization levels; QTIP’s ‘bitshift’ trellis codes are directly aligned with this idea, enabling computed, lookup-free codewords optimized for hardware efficiency.

synthesis_narrative:
QTIP’s central advance is to replace conventional vector quantization in post-training quantization with trellis-coded quantization (TCQ), achieving high-dimensional shaping without the exponential codebook growth that constrains prior VQ-based PTQ. This builds squarely on the TCQ lineage: Marcellin and Fischer established TCQ’s stateful quantizer using Viterbi decoding and set-partitioned labeling, while Gersho and Gray’s classic text formalized both the shaping benefits of high-dimensional quantization and the codebook-scaling barrier in VQ that TCQ circumvents. The trellis and labeling principles trace to Ungerboeck’s trellis-coded modulation, whose set-partitioning directly informs how QTIP designs practical, hardware-efficient trellises.
Crucially, QTIP operationalizes TCQ in the LLM PTQ regime by leveraging the Viterbi algorithm as a lightweight dynamic program across weight sequences, turning the stateful decoder into a throughput benefit rather than a bottleneck. Against the prevailing VQ toolkit, product quantization exemplifies the need to limit subvector dimension to keep codebooks manageable; QTIP avoids this compromise by separating bitrate from effective dimensionality. Moreover, ideas from compositional coding (Additive Quantization) motivate QTIP’s spectrum between lookup-based and computed codes, trading memory for arithmetic while retaining expressivity. Finally, hardware-aware quantization with power-of-two levels (APoT) directly inspires QTIP’s computed, lookup-free “bitshift” trellis codes, aligning the TCQ design with efficient bitshift/add execution. Together, these works converge to enable QTIP’s ultra–high-dimensional, stateful, and hardware-friendly quantization for LLMs.
